ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

FAMILY SERVICE CENTRES

(Counselling services)

     1. Dr Chong Weng Chiew asked the Minister for Community Development and Sports (a) how many of the Family Service Centres (FSC) which provide

Column: 3415

counselling services for crisis management operate beyond office hours; and (b) whether his Ministry will consider rendering FSC more resources to increase the number that can operate beyond office hours, on weekends and public holidays in order to better assist the distressed with urgent counselling needs.

      The Minister for Community Development and Sports (Assoc. Prof. Dr Yaacob Ibrahim): Mr Speaker, Sir, casework and counselling is a core programme of all Family Service Centres (FSCs). All 36 FSCs are open during normal office hours with some extending their operational hours in the evenings to meet the needs of their clients. Where necessary, FSCs will also respond to the cases known to them for crisis management beyond office hours.

 

      Currently, 23 or two-thirds of all FSCs are already providing services beyond office hours. After office hours, families or individuals that need urgent intervention during a crisis can seek assistance from other existing resources within the community. These include 24-hour Helplines such as the Samaritans of Singapore (SOS), as well as crisis shelters. Where relevant, for example, in cases of family violence or child abuse, the public can also call the Neighbourhood Police Centres. FSCs currently work closely with these agencies to follow up on such cases, where necessary.

 

      I am pleased to inform the Member that my Ministry is currently conducting a comprehensive review of FSCs. In this review, we will rationalise and better integrate the role of FSCs and other social service providers to meet the needs of the community. This will include resources required for FSCs to better meet the needs of individuals and families.

      Dr Chong Weng Chiew (Tanjong Pagar):  I would like to ask the Minister

Column: 3416

whether there is any consideration in the review to have all FSCs offer services after office hours, especially with regard to counselling services.

      Assoc. Prof. Dr Yaacob Ibrahim:  Sir, at the moment, we do not see the need for all FSCs to operate beyond office hours.  We have, as mentioned in my reply, 23 out of 36 FSCs operating beyond office hours and some of them do it on their own because they see the need to cater for clients who may need services in the night.   We will ask our FSCs to put up information on the notice board to allow residents who need to get some help after the FSCs have closed for the day to turn to other appropriate agencies.  At the moment, I cannot say confidently that all FSCs do have this information up on their notice board.  We will ask all the FSCs to put up all the relevant information so that in case of an emergency, a family that turns up at a FSC which is closed, they can turn to other sources which are available within the community. 

       Ms Braema Mathiaparanam (Nominated Member):  Could I ask the Minister regarding the national hotline number 1800?  Can that be operated on 24 hours with reference to FSCs locally?  

      Assoc. Prof. Dr Yaacob Ibrahim:  Sir, at the moment, you can call the helpline anytime but there will not be a person after office hours. You can leave a message and someone will call you back. Whether or not we can extend it beyond the normal office hours, we will have to look at that in terms of its viability. 

 

      Assoc. Prof. Ngiam Tee Liang (Nominated Member):  Sir, in view of the new social assistance schemes that are in place or will be in place like HOPE, WAP, etc, FSCs probably would be asked to shoulder more of the cases referred from CDCs and meet-the people sessions and other sources. The question of resources

Column: 3417

is therefore pertinent.  What new measures and provisions will be available for them?

      Assoc. Prof. Dr Yaacob Ibrahim:  Sir, with respect to these new programmes, the resources are now given to the CDCs because the CDCs are managing the programme. But as I have mentioned in my reply, we are reviewing the role of the FSCs and we will study the resources that they may need to carry out these additional responsibilities.

     Dr Chong Weng Chiew:  Sir, I have two supplementary questions.  The first question is currently, all the FSCs have the same funding, regardless of whether or not they provide counselling or crisis management services beyond office hours.  So is there a necessity to review this funding mechansim? 

 

     The second question is this.  I am glad that the Minister mentioned that about two-thirds of the FSCs operate after office hours.  But from what I know, a resident who is not being serviced by one FSC and he goes to another FSC for service, especially in the case of a crisis management, he is expected to pay a fee, and the fee can be as high as $70 per session.  Is there a need to change this practice?

      Assoc. Prof. Dr Yaacob Ibrahim: Sir, all FSCs are given a budget based upon what is the projected workload that they would have to handle every year.  We are reviewing the entire role of FSCs, with a view to strengthening some of the resources that may be needed.  But the principle of whether we want to mandate all FSCs to open up beyond office hours is something that we have to consider very, very carefully.  At the end of the day, we have to see whether or not there is a real need for all FSCs. At the moment, as I have mentioned, 23 FSCs are already open beyond office hours primarily because they want to service some of

Column: 3418

their clients whom they are familiar with, who are working and they come back in the evening. Therefore, they need to meet counsellors beyond office hours.   

 

     Sir, at the moment, MCDS does not feel that there is a need for us to extend the operating hours of all FSCs beyond office hours.  But whether we will increase the funding or not in response to what Prof. Ngiam has asked earlier, because of the additional work, we will study their needs carefully. 

 

      On the second question, all FSCs impose a charge for counselling.  It ranges from being free up to about $50 or so.  If a particular constituent is referred to or goes to another FSC outside his boundary, he will also be charged. The charge has nothing to do with the fact that he is outside that boundary because all FSCs impose a small fee.  But, Sir, any client who comes to the FSC and who cannot pay will not be turned away.  That is the fundamental principle.  If the hon. Member knows of any specific case that warrants my attention, I would be most happy to look into it.

NORMAL (TECHNICAL) AND NORMAL (ACADEMIC) STREAMS

(Criteria for transfer)

     2. Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan asked the Acting Minister for Education (a) what are the criteria for Normal (Technical) students to be transferred to the Normal (Academic) stream and the levels at which such transfers can take place; (b) whether these criteria will be reviewed to allow more opportunities for Normal (Technical) students who have the inclination and aptitude to switch streams; and (c) what is the percentage and number of Normal (Technical) students who are transferred to the Normal (Academic) stream per year over the past five years.

Column: 3419

     The Acting Minister for Education (Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam):  Mr Speaker, Sir, students from the Normal (Technical) course may be transferred to the Normal (Academic) course if they display the interest and aptitude for academic courses. Students need to attain an average score of 70% or higher for all subjects in the Normal (Technical) course to be eligible for the transfer. Most transfers take place at the end of Secondary 1 so that the students would have adequate time to adjust to an academic course and prepare for the 'N' Level examinations at Secondary 4.

 

      In addition, Secondary 4 Normal (Technical) students may be promoted to the Secondary 5 Normal course if they obtain grade 1 in English and Mathematics as well as grade 3 or better in one other subject at the 'N' Level examinations at the end of Secondary 4.

 

      In the last five years, an average of 350 Normal (Technical) students, or about 4.9% of each Secondary 1 Normal (Technical) cohort, were transferred to the Normal (Academic) stream each year.

 

      Dr Amy Khor has asked if these criteria will be reviewed to allow more opportunities for Normal (Technical) students, who have the inclination and aptitude, to switch streams. The criteria for transfer seek to ensure that only academically-inclined students, who can benefit from an academic course, will qualify. We should not equate success for Normal (Technical) students with transferring to an academic stream. Progress up the path of technical education is an achievement no less valid than moving up the academic pathway. We will continue to encourage and help Normal (Technical) students, whose needs and abilities are best catered to by a technically-oriented education, to progress as far as possible in their studies, to post-secondary education in ITE and beyond.

 

Column: 3420

      MOE is conducting a review on the Normal (Technical) curriculum, its delivery and its assessment system.   The review will consider how we can better gear the Normal (Technical) programme for our technically-oriented students.

 

      To introduce greater flexibility within the Normal (Technical) course, we will also allow Normal (Technical) students with relatively strong abilities in certain subjects to proceed faster in those areas. They will be able to offer 1-2 Normal (Academic) subjects in areas in which they have particularly strong strengths.  This flexibility allows us to better cater to some of our students' diverse abilities. We are already doing the same for Normal (Academic) students who have, from this year, been allowed to do two 'O' level subjects at Secondary 4. 

      Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan (Hong Kah):  Firstly, could the Minister comment on the performance of the Normal (Technical) students who get transferred to the Normal (Academic) stream?

 

      Secondly, I would like to ask the Minister if he could confirm that it would be difficult, if not, impossible to get transferred from the Normal (Technical) to Normal (Academic) at the Secondary 2 level even if at Secondary 2 level, the student actually complies with the 70% pass mark for all subjects.

      Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam:   On the first question, because we allow Normal (Technical) students to be transferred to a Normal (Academic) stream only when it is clear that they have the academic aptitude and interest for an academic course, the students who have been transferred have been able to do reasonably well in the Normal (Academic) course.  I do not have the exact data with me but they have in general not failed.

 

Column: 3421

     On the second question, there are a few students who are transferred at Secondary 2. The numbers are small and that is not surprising because most students in fact show aptitude by the end of Secondary 1.  In fact, in primary school, at the end of Primary 5, those students who are capable of coping with the EM2 course, are already transferred at that point.  On an exceptional basis, some students are transferred in Secondary 2.  The teachers and the schools have to be convinced that the students are able to cope with an academic course.  But, like I have said, it is not surprising that the numbers are small. 

Column: 3421

FREE SCHOOL TEXTBOOKS

     3.  Ms Braema Mathiaparanam asked the Acting Minister for Education (a) how many students applied for free textbooks for this school year (2003); (b) how many were successful in their applications; (c) what are the criteria used to process such applications; and (d) whether the Ministry will look into why it is necessary for the content of primary school textbooks and workbooks to be changed each year and split into two sections, making it difficult for children to share their books across the years.

      Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam:  Mr Speaker, Sir, under the Ministry of Education Financial Assistance Scheme (MOE FAS), needy students can apply for waiver of school fees and part of the miscellaneous fees, as well as free textbooks if they are in primary or secondary schools. For junior college students, recipients of the MOE Financial Assistance Scheme receive a bursary of $500 which they can use to buy textbooks and other necessities. As at October 2003, there were 10,729 students receiving assistance under the MOE Financial Assistance Scheme. We do not track the number of applications received.

 

Column: 3422

    The income criteria for the MOE Financial Assistance Scheme are pegged to that for the MCDS' Public Assistance scheme. They were last revised in January 2003. Under the existing criteria, a citizen student would be eligible for the MOE Financial Assistance Scheme if the family's gross monthly income does not exceed $900 for families with one or two children, and $1,050 for families with three or more children.

 

 

   Ms Braema Mathi asked why it is necessary for the content of primary school textbooks and workbooks to be changed each year. This is not the case. New or revised instructional materials are introduced together with revisions to our syllabuses which take place every six years. These revisions are to ensure that what is taught to our students is forward looking and remains relevant to our needs.

 

      Ms Braema Mathiaparanam:   May I ask the Minister that it is great that the content remains more or less stable for six years. Is there any guidance that the Ministry can give the publishers such that the textbooks do not get printed with new inclusions that children cannot share textbooks across years? 

     Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam:  As long as the syllabus remains unchanged, it is not of material significance whether one publisher comes out with a new textbook to improve on what another publisher has produced.  If the syllabus is unchanged and these are textbooks which are used by our schools, they are all equally good. But the Ministry is not responsible for deciding on whether improvements or enhancements are to be made by individual publishers.


     Ms Braema Mathiaparanam:  Does the Ministry issue any guidelines then, please?

     Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam:  We certainly do not require publishers to keep updating their textbooks every year.

Column: 3423

MINISTRIES AND STATUTORY BOARDS

(Review of organisational structures)

     4. Mdm Ho Geok Choo asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance (a) what steps are being taken to review the organisational structures of the various Ministries and Statutory Boards with a view to having a flatter structure and lesser layers, in line with the mission of the Cut Waste Panel; and (b) what will be the estimated number of positions in the whole Government machinery that could be collapsed, re-combined or re-designed for greater efficiency.

     The Second Minister for Finance (Mr Lim Hng Kiang) (for the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance):  It is not practical for the Ministry of Finance to approach the Cut Waste Exercise on the basis of studying every organisation to see how it could or should be restructured.  This will require armies of consultants.  Ministries and statutory boards would be very defensive of what they do and the external auditors will have a hard time figuring out what to cut, and where. 

 

     Restructuring efforts yield worthwhile results only when the organisations themselves see the need to change and want to economise and cut waste so as to release their resources to improve or offer services of higher priority.  My Ministry has, therefore, sought to force ministries to reassess their priorities and seek economies through two actions.  First, by setting a clear upper bound on their budgets, and second, by making clear the requirement for best sourcing. 

 

     Expenditure budgets must adjust with revenues.  When GDP and revenues go down, the Government is prepared to have budget deficits to help businesses and Singaporeans cope.  However, we cannot have deficits year after year as a

Column: 3424

standing practice.  It will undermine fiscal discipline and Singapore's financial standing.  This is why ministries' budgets are kept and pegged to Singapore's GDP.  Once the budgets are set, ministries are left to decide how best to operate within their own budgets. 

 

   When budgets are tight, ministries need to make trade-offs on where to spend the money.  Some ministries would decide on a head-count freeze.  Others may decide to cut expenditure on areas like infrastructure and hardware.  A freeze on teacher recruitment, for example, is not a good idea for the Ministry of Education, whereas slowing down their school upgrading programme is probably more viable.  The Ministry of Finance and the Ministry of Trade and Industry, on the other hand, have implemented head-count freezes.  The Ministries of Health and Home Affairs cannot have head-count freezes because of the challenges created by SARS and the terrorism threat.  They have to find other ways to cut costs.  We have, therefore, left it to each ministry to decide where best to spend their resources to achieve the best outcomes.  But everyone knows that, as a rule, their budgets will go up and down with the GDP.  Nevertheless, when new expenditure is necessary, as in the setting of the Workforce Development Authority, we must be prepared to spend.  So it is not possible for the Ministry of Finance to pre-determine or to estimate the number of positions in the whole Government machinery that could be saved through greater efficiency, restructuring and cutting down of waste. 

 

     What we do know is that results of international surveys have shown that the Singapore Civil Service is consistently ranked among the lowest in terms of relative head-count and expenditure as compared to countries such as Australia, Japan, Finland, Canada, the US and UK.  Notwithstanding this, the Government is aware of the need to be lean and prudent

Column: 3425

in expenditure.  But it will not be wise to simply set a target upfront of the number of positions or officers which has to be reduced.  For example, defence, education and health, together account for more than half of all Government spending.  We can cut the spending in these areas, and reduce the number of people employed in these sectors.  But this would definitely mean that we will weaken the SAF, reduce the teacher-student ratio in schools and reduce the standard of subsidised healthcare in our hospitals.  I am sure this is not the outcome that we want.  So we have to approach restructuring and cutting waste in a pragmatic way.

     Mdm Ho Geok Choo (West Coast):  In a typical structure in a ministry, is it right to say that we normally have a divisional director, a deputy director, a senior manager, followed by a manager and assistant manager?  Can the Minister enlighten what would be the distinction between the areas of responsibilities and the scope of authority of these various positions in the hierarchy?

 

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang:   Members should not get the impression that just because we have a director, deputy director, assistant director, managers, that workflow goes up in a very hierarchical manner.  In fact, most of the ministry headquarters are structured as teams looking after different areas.  These designations are just to reflect the seniority of the people.  You will find that many directors do a lot of leg-work.  They write their own papers, they do their own secretarial support and they do the whole range of policy research, formulation and development.  So please do not be mistaken that just because we have different designations, which should really reflect the grade and experience of the officers, that submissions go layer by layer.  That is not the case. 

Column: 3426

GOVERNMENT-LINKED COMPANIES AND TEMASEK GROUP

(Foreign Chief Executive Officers employed)

     5. Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance (a) what is the number of foreign chief executive officers employed by Government-linked companies and the Temasek group in the last six years; and (b) of the number employed, how many are still in Singapore and serving with these companies.

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang (for the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance):  Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government does not keep track of CEOs of Government-linked companies.  The respective Boards of Directors are responsible for the selection and replacement of their CEOs. 

     Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong (Non-Constituency Member):  Mr Speaker, Sir, we have been seeing a lot of resignations from CEOs and those employed by the GLCs.  After getting their good deal as foreign talents, we see many of them quitting within a few years of getting their huge compensation and sign-on bonuses.  Some of them are allowed to keep the stock options for many years to come, like the SGX's former CEO.  Are we becoming money-foolish in our search for foreign talents?  Are we spending too much for them and giving them a good deal at the expense of our GLCs?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang:   Mr Speaker, Sir, as I have said just now, the appointment, the terms of remuneration, etc, of CEOs are left to the respective Boards of Directors.  It is not the intention of the Government to keep track of these conditions.  The second point is SGX is not a Government-linked company.

SECURITY GUARDS

(Certification and training requirements)

     6. Mr Charles Chong asked the Minister for Home Affairs what is (a) the number of agency security guards who have been certified under the National Skill Recognition Scheme (NSRS) and the estimated number yet to complete training and certification; and (b) the pass rate of those taking the test for NSRS certification and the reasons for the low pass rate.

 

     7. Mr Charles Chong asked the Minister for Home Affairs what security screening and training requirements need to be fulfilled by private and agency security personnel before they are permitted to be deployed as security guards.

 

     Mr Charles Chong (Pasir-Ris-Punggol):  Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to declare my interest as the Patron of the Securities Association of Singapore.

     The Senior Minister of State for Home Affairs (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Home Affairs):  Mr Speaker, Sir, could I have your permission to take both Questions together as they are related?

     Mr Speaker:  Yes.

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee:  Sir, currently, a security agency must submit to Police the personal particulars of any person whom they wish to deploy as a security guard.  Police will then screen the person for his conviction records and assess his suitability to be a security guard.

 

     Since November last year, Police has adopted the National Skills Recognition System or NSRS framework to help raise the level of training in the security guard industry.  NSRS is the national framework

Column: 3428

for establishing work performance standards, identifying job competencies and certifying skills acquisition.  There are currently nine NSRS skills standards developed for the security guard industry.  Police has adopted two of these for licensing purposes, namely, guarding and patrolling, and incident management.  Under Police's licensing requirements, every security guard is required to attend a 5-day course at any of the 17 NSRS approved training centres, where they will receive training on skills such as how to perform access control and patrols, manage bomb threat incidents, preserve crime scenes, provide first aid and use a fire extinguisher.  These are basic skills that every security guard should have.  At the end of the course, they will be tested by an independent assessor appointed by the Workforce Development Agency (WDA).

 

     Currently, there are 10,000 security guards employed by private security agencies.  As at end October this year, 3,400 security guards have been assessed on the two skills standards that I mentioned earlier. 2,150 or 63% passed.  The other 1,250 failed in either one or both of the skills standards.

 

     Of the remaining 6,600 security guards who have not been assessed under the NSRS, 4,400 have been exempted as their previous training and experience were assessed by Police to be adequate for their job.  Hence, only 2,200 security guards have yet to complete the NSRS training and obtain the certification. Police have given them up till March 2005 to obtain their certification.

 

     Compared to the average pass rate of 89% across all industries implementing NSRS, the pass rate of 63% for the security guard industry would appear low.  The WDA, which administers the NSRS, has assessed that this is partly due to the inadequate training provided by security agencies to their security guards.  

Column: 3429

Many security guards who attended the NSRS did not demonstrate sufficient understanding and practical knowledge of the work procedures involved.  Some even indicated that they did not know what to expect of these assessments and were thus not prepared for them. The current security climate makes it all the more pressing for the industry to level up its standards.

 

     Sir, the NSRS framework was only introduced for the security industry a year ago.  It will take time for the industry to adapt to a rigorous competency-based assessment framework.  Police and MOM will continue to work with the security industry to improve the quality of their services.
